docs.lead_paragraph: Few politicians were willing on Wednesday afternoon to heartily endorse the Senate Finance Committee's approach to health care reform.

headline.main: A Sampling of Reactions to the Baucus Plan
headline.print_headline: A Sampling of Reactions to the Baucus Plan

docs.snippet: Few politicians were willing on Wednesday afternoon to heartily endorse the Senate Finance Committee's approach to health care reform.

docs.lead_paragraph: Few players in the health care debate gave the Baucus plan unqualified endorsements on Wednesday afternoon. Instead, most described it as a starting point for the hard bargaining to come. Here's a smattering of reactions across the political spectrum.

headline.main: A Sampling of Reactions to the Baucus Plan

docs.abstract: Few politicians were willing on Wednesday afternoon to heartily endorse the Senate Finance Committee's approach to health care reform.
docs.snippet: Few politicians were willing on Wednesday afternoon to heartily endorse the Senate Finance Committee's approach to health care reform.

docs.lead_paragraph: In his speech accepting the presidency of the A.F.L.-C.I.O on Wednesday, Richard L. Trumka dove headfirst into the health care debate.

headline.main: New A.F.L.-C.I.O. Leader Calls for Public Option

docs.abstract: The A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s incoming president implores Obama and Congress to push for a public insurance plan.
docs.snippet: The A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s incoming president implores Obama and Congress to push for a public insurance plan.

docs.lead_paragraph: I got the e-mail late last Wednesday night. We'd watched President Obama's speech on health care at a friend's house, and I was getting ready for bed since I had to be at the hospital at 7 the next morning for work.
docs.abstract: When nurse Theresa Brown wrote about health reform, she never expected to get a call from the White House.
docs.snippet: When nurse Theresa Brown wrote about health reform, she never expected to get a call from the White House.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama talks a lot about how Americans who like their health insurance will be able to keep it. But Americans who hate their insurance might be able to dump it, according to the proposal unveiled today by Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana.

headline.main: Hate Your Insurance? Tell Mr. Baucus and Us All About It

docs.abstract: Hate your insurance? Then maybe you'll love what Senator Baucus wants to offer you. Join the discussion.
docs.snippet: Hate your insurance? Then maybe you'll love what Senator Baucus wants to offer you. Join the discussion.

docs.lead_paragraph: Updated, Sept. 17, 12:50 p.m. | Gail Wilensky, of Project Hope, a health policy group, says that on balance the Baucus plan is better than other bills under consideration.
docs.abstract: What are the Baucus bill's strengths and flaws? Does it achieve the broad goal of health reform?
docs.snippet: What are the Baucus bill's strengths and flaws? Does it achieve the broad goal of health reform?

docs.lead_paragraph: Over at the Prescriptions blog, my colleague Reed Abelson describes the findings of the Kaiser Family Foundation's latest benefits survey. The headline number: The average cost of a family policy is now $13,375 a year, and has doubled in a decade.

headline.main: Your Health Care Benefits, in Charts

docs.abstract: The average cost of a family health insurance policy is now $13,375 a year, and other findings from the Kaiser Family Foundation's annual benefits survey.
docs.snippet: The average cost of a family health insurance policy is now $13,375 a year, and other findings from the Kaiser Family Foundation's annual benefits survey.

docs.lead_paragraph: While all eyes have been on Senate Republicans to see if any will support the Baucus plan, there is reason to believe a slow leak could be occurring on the Democratic side.
docs.abstract: Senator Casey's comments may indicate a slow leak in Democratic support for the Baucus plan.
docs.snippet: Senator Casey's comments may indicate a slow leak in Democratic support for the Baucus plan.

docs.lead_paragraph: David Brooks: Gail, many years ago, I was a sophisticated person. I used to listen to classical music: Duke Ellington, Benny Goodman, Herbie Hancock and Weather Report, along with the ubiquitous Bruce. But as I age, my musical tastes more and more resemble that of a tween.
docs.abstract: Why does it seem like this country is in a state of decline?
docs.snippet: Why does it seem like this country is in a state of decline?

byline.original: By DAVID BROOKS AND GAIL COLLINS

docs.lead_paragraph: The House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, released a statement Wednesday about the Baucus health-care proposal. Notably, while she says she still believes a public option is "the best way" to lower costs, she seems to have dropped her insistence that any bill contain a government-run insurance alternative to private coverage.

headline.main: Pelosi Still Wants Public Option, but Drops Insistence

docs.abstract: House Speaker Pelosi responds to Baucus proposal with a call for a public insurance plan -- although she no longer seems to be demanding it.
docs.snippet: House Speaker Pelosi responds to Baucus proposal with a call for a public insurance plan -- although she no longer seems to be demanding it.
